value: caption=The rock formation that gives Window Rock its name.

(Navajo: Tségháhoodzání) is a small town in Apache County, in the state of
. It is significant beyond its size as the administrative center of
, the country's largest Indian reservation and an important tourist destination.
Window Rock is just west of the
state line and is more easily reached by road from New Mexico than from Arizona. NM SR 264 leads from
) to the town. The southwestern approach to the town is via US highway 191 from I-40.
It's a small town; just walk, bike or drive.

value: name=Navajo Nation Museum, Library, & Visitor's Center
address=Hwy 264 & Postal Loop Road., Window Rock, AZ. 86515
directions=1/4th mile west of Arizona/New Mexico State border. 26 miles from Gallup

content=The modern Navajo Nation Museum is dedicated to preserving and interpreting the rich and unique culture of the Navajo Nation. Native displays, a book and gift shop, snack bar, auditorium, outdoor amphitheater, information kiosk, library, and on-site traditional Navajo hogan complete the center.
The Museum is open from 8AM-6PM (winter hours)/8AM-7PM (summer hours) Tuesday-Friday, 8AM-5PM Monday and Saturday.

article for a discussion of Navajo rugs and other distinctive arts and crafts of the region.
is headquartered in Window Rock (SR 264 just east of the center of town) and may be worth a visit, not so much for buying goods as for learning about other places in the region for buying them.
Try out the local frybread stands, most near the downtown fleamarket.

Alcoholic beverages are prohibited within Navajo Nation. If you simply must have a beer,
, New Mexico is only a few miles away, but bar-hopping there may expose you to some hostility, owing to problems with alcoholism in Navajo Nation.
Lodging is limited, but try the
, 48 W. Highway 264, 928-871-4108, and report on it here.

value: Window Rock is a good base camp from which to visit some of the
trading posts and look for Navajo rugs and other folk art.
Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site

system, but is also a working post with a good collection of rugs and jewelry. Posts at Crystal (picturesque setting, quite different from the desert you might be expecting), Two Grey Hills (a particularly noted rug-weaving region), and Wide Ruin are also close.
